what: Adjust AGB map by removing predicted bias — adjustMapBias
title: Adjust AGB map by removing predicted bias — adjustMapBias
text: function adjusts AGB map subtracting predicted bias, optionally applies forest mask, calculates regional totals comparison. allows provide bias-corrected AGB estimates pixel regional scales.

title: Adjust AGB map by removing predicted bias — adjustMapBias
code: adjustMapBias(   map_agb,   bias_map,   forest_mask = NULL,   threshold = 10,   scale_factor = NULL,   return_totals = TRUE )

title: Adjust AGB map by removing predicted bias — adjustMapBias
text: map_agb SpatRaster object containing original AGB map adjusted. Values Mg/ha. typically map used earlier steps bias modeling workflow. bias_map SpatRaster object containing predicted bias predictBiasMap. Must extent, resolution, CRS map_agb. Values Mg/ha. forest_mask Optional SpatRaster object forest masking, typically tree cover layer. provided, used together threshold define forest areas regional total calculations. NULL (default), masking applied. threshold Numeric value (0-100) specifying minimum tree cover percentage considered forest. used forest_mask provided. Default 10 (.e., areas <10% tree cover excluded). Set 0 include areas tree cover. scale_factor Numeric value scaling pixel-level values regional totals. Typically calculated (resolution_in_meters^2) / 10000 convert per-hectare total. NULL (default), automatically calculated raster resolution assuming input resolution degrees. return_totals Logical indicating whether calculate regional totals. Default TRUE. FALSE, adjusted raster returned without total calculations.

title: Adjust AGB map by removing predicted bias — adjustMapBias
text: return_totals = TRUE, returns list : adjusted_map SpatRaster bias-adjusted AGB values (Mg/ha). Calculated : adjusted = original - predicted_bias default_total Numeric, total AGB original map Mg (return_totals=TRUE) adjusted_total Numeric, total AGB adjusted map Mg (return_totals=TRUE) difference Numeric, difference adjusted default totals Mg. Positive values indicate adjusted estimate higher. percent_change Numeric, percentage change default adjusted. Formula: 100 * (adjusted - default) / default n_cells Integer, number cells included totals calculation (masking) return_totals = FALSE, returns adjusted_map SpatRaster.

title: Adjust AGB map by removing predicted bias — adjustMapBias
text: bias adjustment follows simple subtraction approach: $$AGB_{adjusted} = AGB_{original} - bias_{predicted}$$ bias_predicted output predictBiasMap. Areas model predicted positive bias (map overestimation) AGB reduced. Areas negative bias (map underestimation) AGB increased. Regional totals calculated summing pixel values (forest masking) multiplying scale factor convert per-hectare total biomass. scale factor accounts pixel size: $$Total = \sum (AGB_{pixel} \times PixelArea)$$ example, 0.1-degree pixels equator (~11km), scale factor approximately (11000^2) / 10000 = 12100.

title: Adjust AGB map by removing predicted bias — adjustMapBias
text: Araza, ., et al. (2022). comprehensive framework assessing accuracy uncertainty global -ground biomass maps. Remote Sensing Environment, 272, 112917. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rse.2022.112917

title: Adjust AGB map by removing predicted bias — adjustMapBias
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Following from predictBiasMap example # Assuming map_agb and bias_map are already created  # Simple adjustment without masking adjusted <- adjustMapBias(   map_agb = map_layer,   bias_map = bias_map,   return_totals = FALSE )  plot(adjusted, main = "Bias-Adjusted AGB (Mg/ha)")  # Adjustment with forest mask and regional totals result <- adjustMapBias(   map_agb = map_layer,   bias_map = bias_map,   forest_mask = treecover_layer,   threshold = 10,   return_totals = TRUE )  # Compare totals print(result$default_total) print(result$adjusted_total) print(result$percent_change)  # Visualize difference plot(result$adjusted_map - map_layer, main = "Change in AGB (Mg/ha)") } # }

what: Aggregate Uncertainty Accounting for Spatial Correlation — aggregateUncertainty
title: Aggregate Uncertainty Accounting for Spatial Correlation — aggregateUncertainty
text: Aggregates pixel-level standard deviation regional scale accounting spatial correlation using variogram-based correlation matrix. critical accurate uncertainty quantification ignoring spatial correlation leads underestimation regional-scale uncertainty.

title: Aggregate Uncertainty Accounting for Spatial Correlation — aggregateUncertainty
code: aggregateUncertainty(   sd_raster,   variogram_model,   resolution = 0.1,   forest_mask = NULL,   filename = NULL,   return_comparison = TRUE,   scale_factor = 10000,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Aggregate Uncertainty Accounting for Spatial Correlation — aggregateUncertainty
text: sd_raster SpatRaster containing pixel-level standard deviation AGB (Mg/ha). Must extent resolution AGB map. variogram_model discountedVariogram object discountVariogram(), gstat vgm object containing fitted (optionally discounted) variogram parameters. Used create spatial correlation matrix. resolution Numeric. Resolution (degrees CRS units) aggregation. Default: 0.1 (roughly 10 km equator). Defines window size focal aggregation. match scale regional reporting units. forest_mask Optional SpatRaster forest/non-forest mask. forest pixels (mask > 0) included aggregation. Default: NULL (pixels used). filename Optional. File path save aggregated SD raster. Default: NULL (raster kept memory). return_comparison Logical. comparison statistics (vs. without correlation) calculated? Default: TRUE. Useful assessing impact spatial correlation regional uncertainty. scale_factor Numeric. Conversion factor pixel units regional totals. Default: 10000 (converts 100m pixels hectares using 0.1° aggregation). Used scale SD mean per-pixel values regional total values. verbose Logical. Print progress messages? Default: TRUE.

title: Aggregate Uncertainty Accounting for Spatial Correlation — aggregateUncertainty
text: list class "aggregatedUncertainty" containing: aggregated_sd_raster SpatRaster aggregated SD values accounting spatial correlation (Mg) sd_no_correlation SpatRaster aggregated SD assuming independence (Mg). return_comparison=TRUE correlation_matrix Matrix used focal window correlation weighting regional_sd_correlated Numeric. Total regional SD accounting correlation (Mg) regional_sd_independent Numeric. Total regional SD assuming independence (Mg). return_comparison=TRUE correlation_reduction_factor Numeric. Ratio correlated independent SD. Values < 1 indicate spatial correlation reduces total uncertainty. return_comparison=TRUE n_cells Integer. Number cells included aggregation resolution Numeric. Aggregation resolution used

title: Aggregate Uncertainty Accounting for Spatial Correlation — aggregateUncertainty
text: function implements focal window correlation approach Section 5 Mexico demo notebook (lines 1215-1305). workflow : Create correlation matrix variogram using corMatrix() helper Apply forest mask provided Use terra::focal() correlation matrix weights Calculate weighted sum: sum(SD_i * SD_j * cor_ij) Take square root get aggregated SD Scale regional totals using scale_factor Spatial correlation aggregation: aggregating uncertainty pixels regions, must account spatial correlation. variance sum correlated variables : $$Var(\sum X_i) = \sum_i \sum_j SD_i \times SD_j \times \rho_{ij}$$ correlation ignored (independence assumption), reduces : $$Var(\sum X_i) = \sum_i SD_i^2$$ Positive spatial correlation increases regional variance compared independence assumption, nearby pixels tend errors direction. Correlation matrix: correlation matrix created variogram using helper function corMatrix(), converts semivariance γ(h) correlation ρ(h): $$\rho(h) = 1 - \gamma(h) / sill$$ matrix defines correlation weights focal window aggregation. Resolution scale: resolution parameter match reporting units (e.g., 0.1° regional estimates, 1° country-level). scale_factor converts pixel-level SD regional total SD based pixel size aggregation area.

title: Aggregate Uncertainty Accounting for Spatial Correlation — aggregateUncertainty
text: Araza, ., de Bruin, S., Herold, M., Quegan, S., Labrière, N., Rodriguez-Veiga, P., ... & Burt, . (2022). comprehensive framework assessing accuracy uncertainty global -ground biomass maps. Remote Sensing Environment, 272, 112917.

title: Aggregate Uncertainty Accounting for Spatial Correlation — aggregateUncertainty
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Assuming you have a discounted variogram: vgm_discounted <- discountVariogram(vgm_fit, variance_data)  # Aggregate uncertainty with spatial correlation uncertainty_agg <- aggregateUncertainty(   sd_raster = sd_map,   variogram_model = vgm_discounted,   resolution = 0.1,   forest_mask = forest_raster,   return_comparison = TRUE )  # Inspect results print(uncertainty_agg$regional_sd_correlated) print(uncertainty_agg$regional_sd_independent) print(uncertainty_agg$correlation_reduction_factor)  # Plot aggregated SD terra::plot(uncertainty_agg$aggregated_sd_raster,             main = "Aggregated SD (with correlation)") } # }

what: Calculate Bias-Adjusted Regional Totals with Uncertainty — biasAdjustedTotal
title: Calculate Bias-Adjusted Regional Totals with Uncertainty — biasAdjustedTotal
text: Calculates regional AGB totals default bias-adjusted maps, including uncertainty bounds accounting spatial correlation. Provides complete comparison showing impact bias correction proper uncertainty quantification.

title: Calculate Bias-Adjusted Regional Totals with Uncertainty — biasAdjustedTotal
code: biasAdjustedTotal(   map_agb_default,   map_agb_adjusted,   aggregated_uncertainty,   forest_mask = NULL,   threshold = 10,   confidence_level = 0.95,   scale_factor = 10000,   return_details = TRUE )

title: Calculate Bias-Adjusted Regional Totals with Uncertainty — biasAdjustedTotal
text: map_agb_default SpatRaster containing default (uncorrected) AGB map (Mg/ha). map_agb_adjusted SpatRaster containing bias-adjusted AGB map (Mg/ha). Typically adjustMapBias(). aggregated_uncertainty aggregatedUncertainty object aggregateUncertainty(), containing aggregated SD raster regional SD values. Alternatively, SpatRaster aggregated SD values. forest_mask Optional SpatRaster forest/non-forest mask (typically tree cover percentage). Used together threshold define forest areas. Default: NULL (pixels used). threshold Numeric value (0-100) specifying minimum tree cover percentage considered forest. used forest_mask provided. Default: 10 (areas <10% tree cover excluded). Set 0 include areas. confidence_level Numeric. Confidence level intervals. Default: 0.95 (95% confidence intervals). Common values: 0.90, 0.95, 0.99. scale_factor Numeric. Conversion factor pixel values regional totals. Default: 10000 (converts 100m pixels hectares 0.1° aggregation). Must match scale_factor used aggregateUncertainty(). return_details Logical. detailed statistics included? Default: TRUE. Includes CV%, relative uncertainty, number cells, etc.

title: Calculate Bias-Adjusted Regional Totals with Uncertainty — biasAdjustedTotal
text: data.frame one row per map type (default, bias_adjusted) columns: map_type Character. "default" "bias_adjusted" total_Mg Numeric. Regional AGB total (Mg) sd_Mg Numeric. Standard deviation total (Mg) cv_percent Numeric. Coefficient variation (SD/mean * 100) ci_lower Numeric. Lower confidence bound (Mg) ci_upper Numeric. Upper confidence bound (Mg) confidence_level Numeric. Confidence level used (e.g., 0.95) n_cells Integer. Number pixels included mean_agb_Mg_ha Numeric. Mean AGB per hectare (return_details=TRUE) sd_mean_Mg_ha Numeric. SD mean per hectare (return_details=TRUE) Additional attributes: bias_correction_effect Numeric. Difference totals (adjusted - default) Mg percent_change Numeric. Percent change default adjusted uncertainty_overlap Logical. confidence intervals overlap?

title: Calculate Bias-Adjusted Regional Totals with Uncertainty — biasAdjustedTotal
text: function integrates complete bias modeling uncertainty quantification workflow Sections 4-5 Mexico demo notebook (lines 1079-1305). Regional totals calculation: map (default bias-adjusted): Apply forest mask threshold Sum pixel values multiply scale_factor Extract calculate regional SD Calculate confidence intervals: total ± (z * SD) Confidence intervals: Confidence intervals calculated using normal approximation: $$CI = total \pm z_{\alpha/2} \times SD$$ z critical value standard normal distribution (e.g., 1.96 95% confidence). Coefficient variation (CV%): CV normalized measure uncertainty: $$CV = (SD / mean) \times 100$$ Values < 10% indicate low uncertainty, 10-30% moderate, > 30% high. Interpretation: Compare two rows assess: Bias correction impact: much total change? Statistical significance: confidence intervals overlap? Relative uncertainty: CV% acceptable reporting? IPCC compliance: uncertainty bounds suitable inventory?

title: Calculate Bias-Adjusted Regional Totals with Uncertainty — biasAdjustedTotal
text: Araza, ., de Bruin, S., Herold, M., Quegan, S., Labrière, N., Rodriguez-Veiga, P., ... & Burt, . (2022). comprehensive framework assessing accuracy uncertainty global -ground biomass maps. Remote Sensing Environment, 272, 112917. IPCC (2006). IPCC Guidelines National Greenhouse Gas Inventories.

title: Calculate Bias-Adjusted Regional Totals with Uncertainty — biasAdjustedTotal
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Complete workflow: # 1. Bias modeling bias_data <- extractBiasCovariates(plots, map_agb, map_sd, covariates) bias_model <- trainBiasModel(bias_data, predictors = c("map", "sd", "height")) bias_map <- predictBiasMap(bias_model, covariate_stack) adjustment <- adjustMapBias(map_agb, bias_map, forest_mask)  # 2. Uncertainty quantification bias_data$biasPred <- predict(bias_model$model, data = bias_data) vgm_fit <- fitResidualVariogram(bias_data, map_sd, coord_cols = c("x", "y"), crs = "EPSG:4326") vgm_disc <- discountVariogram(vgm_fit, variance_data) uncertainty <- aggregateUncertainty(map_sd, vgm_disc, resolution = 0.1)  # 3. Calculate totals with uncertainty totals <- biasAdjustedTotal(   map_agb_default = map_agb,   map_agb_adjusted = adjustment$adjusted_map,   aggregated_uncertainty = uncertainty,   forest_mask = forest_mask,   confidence_level = 0.95 )  # Inspect results print(totals) print(attr(totals, "bias_correction_effect")) print(attr(totals, "uncertainty_overlap")) } # }

what: Comprehensive uncertainty calculation for all plot data types — calculateTotalUncertainty
title: Comprehensive uncertainty calculation for all plot data types — calculateTotalUncertainty
text: function provides unified framework calculating uncertainty across different plot data types. automatically detects plot data type, preserves existing uncertainty components present, calculates missing components needed.

title: Comprehensive uncertainty calculation for all plot data types — calculateTotalUncertainty
code: calculateTotalUncertainty(   plot_data,   map_year,   map_resolution = 100,   biome_info = TRUE,   se_data = NULL )

title: Comprehensive uncertainty calculation for all plot data types — calculateTotalUncertainty
text: plot_data data frame containing plot data. Required columns: PLOT_ID - Plot identifier AGB_T_HA - -ground biomass tons per hectare SIZE_HA - Plot size hectares GEZ - Global ecological zone (e.g., "Tropical", "Temperate", "Boreal", "Subtropical") Additional columns required biome_info=TRUE: ZONE - Continental zone (e.g., "Europe", "Asia", "Africa") AVG_YEAR - Year plot measurement temporal adjustment sdTree, sdSE, sdGrowth columns exist, preserved. map_year Numeric value indicating map year temporal adjustment. used calculate growth uncertainty based time difference plot measurement map production. map_resolution Numeric value indicating map resolution meters (default: 100). affects sampling error calculations based difference plot size pixel size. biome_info Logical indicating whether use biome information (GEZ column) growth uncertainty calculation (default: TRUE). TRUE, function uses TempVar requires 'ZONE', 'GEZ', 'AVG_YEAR' columns present plot_data. FALSE, function requires sdGrowth column provided input data. se_data Optional data frame sampling error data can used instead loading se.csv. Must contain columns: SIZE_HA - Plot size hectares RS_HA - Pixel resolution hectares ratio - Ratio plot size pixel size cv - Coefficient variation (percent)

title: Comprehensive uncertainty calculation for all plot data types — calculateTotalUncertainty
text: list containing: data input plot data additional uncertainty columns: sdTree - Standard deviation measurement error sdSE - Standard deviation sampling error sdGrowth - Standard deviation growth/temporal uncertainty varPlot - Total variance (sum squared standard deviations) sdTotal - Total standard deviation (square root varPlot) plot_type detected plot data type: "tree_level", "point", "polygon", "nested", "lidar" uncertainty_components relative contribution uncertainty component proportion total variance

title: Comprehensive uncertainty calculation for all plot data types — calculateTotalUncertainty
text: function handles three primary sources uncertainty: Measurement uncertainty (sdTree): Derived allometric equations, wood density estimates, measurement error. tree-level data, calculated BIOMASS package Monte Carlo methods. plot-level data, estimated using random forest model trained large dataset. Sampling uncertainty (sdSE): Accounts sampling error introduced differing plot sizes vs. pixel sizes, following approach Réjou-Méchain et al. (2014). Growth uncertainty (sdGrowth): Adjusts temporal differences plot measurement year map production year, using growth rates specific ecological zone. components combined using error propagation principles: $$varPlot = sdTree^2 + sdSE^2 + sdGrowth^2$$ $$sdTotal = \sqrt{varPlot}$$

title: Comprehensive uncertainty calculation for all plot data types — calculateTotalUncertainty
text: tree-level data: Uses BIOMASS package Monte Carlo simulations account wood density uncertainty, diameter measurement errors, allometric model errors. plot-level data: Uses random forest model trained thousands plots across biomes predict measurement uncertainty based plot AGB, plot size, ecological zone. pre-existing sdTree column exists, values preserved.

title: Comprehensive uncertainty calculation for all plot data types — calculateTotalUncertainty
text: Uses random forest model trained geo-simulation data relates plot--pixel size ratios coefficient variation. model considers relationship plot size (SIZE_HA), remote sensing pixel size (RS_HA), ratio. resulting coefficient variation converted standard deviation multiplying mean AGB. Custom sampling error data can provided se_data parameter.

title: Comprehensive uncertainty calculation for all plot data types — calculateTotalUncertainty
text: biome_info = TRUE, uses biome-specific growth rates uncertainty TempVar function. function considers time difference plot measurement year (AVG_YEAR) map year. ecological zone (GEZ) processed separately apply biome-specific growth rates. biome information available biome_info = FALSE, function requires sdGrowth column provided input data.

title: Comprehensive uncertainty calculation for all plot data types — calculateTotalUncertainty
text: Combines uncertainty components summing variances: varPlot = sdTree^2 + sdSE^2 + sdGrowth^2 Calculates total standard deviation sdTotal = sqrt(varPlot) Reports relative contribution component total variance.

title: Comprehensive uncertainty calculation for all plot data types — calculateTotalUncertainty
code: # Example 1: Using existing plot data # First load the sample plots dataset included with the package data(plots)  # Create a subset of plots for demonstration set.seed(42) sample_plots <- plots[sample(nrow(plots), 5), ]  # Add biome information (required for uncertainty calculation) sample_plots <- BiomePair(sample_plots)  # Apply TempApplyVar to adjust biomass to map year and calculate temporal variance sample_plots <- TempApplyVar(sample_plots, map_year = 2020)  # Calculate total uncertainty components for map year 2020 result <- calculateTotalUncertainty(sample_plots, map_year = 2020, map_resolution = 100) #> Calculating tree measurement uncertainty using RF model #> Calculating sampling uncertainty using Rejou-Mechain approach #> Loading sampling error data from package file #> Using existing growth uncertainty (sdGrowth) values #> Total uncertainty calculated for plot data of type: point  # See the relative contribution of each uncertainty component result$uncertainty_components #> measurement    sampling      growth  #>   0.2498749   0.3022655   0.4478596   # Example 2: Working with data that already has measurement uncertainty # First process tree-level data to get measurement uncertainty # Load sample tree data tree_data <- utils::read.csv(sample_file("SampleTree.csv")) tree_locations <- utils::read.csv(sample_file("SampleTreeXY.csv"))  # Calculate AGB and measurement uncertainty tree_results <- sd_tree(tree_data, tree_locations, region = "World") #> Using useCache=TRUE is recommended to reduce online search time for the next query #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0% #> Warning: There seem to be a problem reaching the TNRS API! #> Failed to perform HTTP request. #> Taxonomic correction attempt 1 failed: Invalid taxonomic correction results (empty or length mismatch). Retrying in 1 seconds... #> Using useCache=TRUE is recommended to reduce online search time for the next query #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0% #> Warning: There seem to be a problem reaching the TNRS API! #> Failed to perform HTTP request. #> Taxonomic correction attempt 2 failed: Invalid taxonomic correction results (empty or length mismatch). Retrying in 1 seconds... #> Using useCache=TRUE is recommended to reduce online search time for the next query #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0% #> Warning: There seem to be a problem reaching the TNRS API! #> Failed to perform HTTP request. #> Taxonomic correction failed after 3 attempts: Invalid taxonomic correction results (empty or length mismatch). Using original taxonomic names. #> Warning: Taxonomic correction failed after all retry attempts. Using original taxonomic names. #> The reference dataset contains 16467 wood density values #> Your taxonomic table contains 340 taxa #> No tree height data found in original plot data. Calculating height using BIOMASS height-diameter model.  # Add required biome information tree_results <- BiomePair(tree_results)  # Calculate total uncertainty with tree data tree_uncertainty <- calculateTotalUncertainty(tree_results, map_year = 2020) #> Using existing sdTree values for tree_level data #> Calculating sampling uncertainty using Rejou-Mechain approach #> Loading sampling error data from package file #> Calculating growth uncertainty by biome #> Total uncertainty calculated for plot data of type: tree_level  # Example 3: Using custom sampling error data # Create custom sampling error data (coefficient of variation by plot/pixel size ratio) custom_se_data <- data.frame(   SIZE_HA = c(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 1.0),  # Plot sizes in hectares   RS_HA = c(1, 1, 1, 1),            # Remote sensing pixel size in hectares   ratio = c(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 1.0),   # Ratio of plot size to pixel size   cv = c(20, 15, 10, 5)             # Coefficient of variation (%) )  # Calculate uncertainty using custom sampling error model custom_result <- calculateTotalUncertainty(   sample_plots,   map_year = 2020,   map_resolution = 100,   se_data = custom_se_data ) #> Calculating tree measurement uncertainty using RF model #> Calculating sampling uncertainty using Rejou-Mechain approach #> Using provided sampling error data #> Using existing growth uncertainty (sdGrowth) values #> Total uncertainty calculated for plot data of type: point  # Example 4: Using manual growth uncertainty values # First, prepare data with manual sdGrowth values manual_growth_plots <- sample_plots # Add manual growth uncertainty of 7% of AGB manual_growth_plots$sdGrowth <- manual_growth_plots$AGB_T_HA * 0.07  # Now calculate uncertainty with biome_info = FALSE simple_result <- calculateTotalUncertainty(   manual_growth_plots,   map_year = 2020,   map_resolution = 100,   biome_info = FALSE ) #> Calculating tree measurement uncertainty using RF model #> Calculating sampling uncertainty using Rejou-Mechain approach #> Loading sampling error data from package file #> Using existing growth uncertainty (sdGrowth) values #> Total uncertainty calculated for plot data of type: point

what: Discount Variogram Nugget for Plot Measurement Error — discountVariogram
title: Discount Variogram Nugget for Plot Measurement Error — discountVariogram
text: Adjusts variogram nugget account plot-level measurement uncertainty using method Christensen (2011). essential proper uncertainty quantification separates spatial variation (aggregates differently) measurement error ().

title: Discount Variogram Nugget for Plot Measurement Error — discountVariogram
code: discountVariogram(   variogram_fit,   plot_data,   filter_iqr = TRUE,   iqr_mult = 1.5,   transfer_negative = TRUE,   plot = TRUE )

title: Discount Variogram Nugget for Plot Measurement Error — discountVariogram
text: variogram_fit residualVariogram object fitResidualVariogram(), gstat vgm object discounted. plot_data data.frame plot-level variance estimates. Must contain columns: varPlot (plot measurement variance (Mg/ha)²) varMap (map pixel variance (Mg/ha)²). Typically obtained calculateTotalUncertainty() similar. filter_iqr Logical. plots filtered IQR remove extreme variance ratios? Default: TRUE. Christensen (2011) recommends avoid bias outliers. iqr_mult Numeric. IQR multiplier outlier detection. Default: 1.5. Plots varPlot/varMap² outside range [Q1 - iqr_mult * IQR, Q3 + iqr_mult * IQR] removed. transfer_negative Logical. negative nugget values transferred partial sill? Default: TRUE. Prevents invalid variogram models discounting reduces nugget zero. plot Logical. comparison plot generated? Default: TRUE. Shows original vs. discounted variogram models.

title: Discount Variogram Nugget for Plot Measurement Error — discountVariogram
text: list class "discountedVariogram" containing: discounted_variogram gstat vgm object adjusted nugget original_variogram gstat vgm object discounting discount_factor Numeric. discount value subtracted nugget: mean(varPlot / varMap²) nugget_original Numeric. Nugget discounting nugget_discounted Numeric. Nugget discounting (≥ 0) nugget_transferred Numeric. Amount transferred partial sill nugget negative n_plots Integer. Number plots used calculation n_filtered Integer. Number plots removed IQR filtering plot Function generate comparison plot plot=TRUE, NULL otherwise

title: Discount Variogram Nugget for Plot Measurement Error — discountVariogram
text: function implements variogram discounting method Christensen (2011) applied Section 5 Mexico demo notebook (lines 1177-1213). Christensen (2011) method: variogram nugget includes true micro-scale spatial variation plot measurement error. isolate spatial variation, calculate: $$discount = mean(varPlot / varMap^2)$$ adjust nugget: $$nugget_{new} = nugget_{old} - discount$$ IQR filtering: variance ratio varPlot/varMap² can extreme values plots low map variance unusually high plot variance. Christensen (2011) recommends filtering interquartile range (IQR) remove outliers calculating mean discount factor. Negative nugget handling: discounting results negative nugget, nugget set zero negative amount added partial sill. ensures variogram model remains valid preserving total sill. Interpretation: large discount factor indicates plot measurement error substantial component original nugget. discounting, remaining nugget represents true micro-scale spatial variation plus remaining measurement error components.

title: Discount Variogram Nugget for Plot Measurement Error — discountVariogram
text: Christensen, W. F. (2011). Filtered kriging spatial data heterogeneous measurement error variances. Biometrics, 67(3), 947-957.

title: Discount Variogram Nugget for Plot Measurement Error — discountVariogram
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Assuming you have a fitted variogram and plot variance data: vgm_fit <- fitResidualVariogram(   bias_data = bias_data,   map_sd_raster = sd_map,   coord_cols = c("x", "y"),   crs = "EPSG:4326" )  # Calculate plot and map variances (example) variance_data <- data.frame(   varPlot = bias_data$sdPlot^2,  # From field measurement uncertainty   varMap = bias_data$sd^2         # From map pixel SD )  # Discount the variogram vgm_discounted <- discountVariogram(   variogram_fit = vgm_fit,   plot_data = variance_data,   filter_iqr = TRUE,   iqr_mult = 1.5 )  # Inspect results print(vgm_discounted$discount_factor) print(vgm_discounted$discounted_variogram)  # Show comparison plot if (!is.null(vgm_discounted$plot)) {   vgm_discounted$plot() } } # }

title: Extract bias and covariate values at plot locations — extractBiasCovariates
text: function extracts covariate values plot locations calculates bias difference map AGB plot AGB. first step bias modeling workflow, preparing data training bias correction model. function follows methodology Araza et al. (2022) AGB map bias assessment correction.

title: Extract bias and covariate values at plot locations — extractBiasCovariates
code: extractBiasCovariates(   plot_data,   map_agb,   map_sd,   covariates = list(),   plot_agb_col = "plotAGB_10",   map_agb_col = "mapAGB" )

title: Extract bias and covariate values at plot locations — extractBiasCovariates
text: plot_data data.frame containing plot comparison results invDasymetry. Must include columns: x: X-coordinate (longitude) plot locations y: Y-coordinate (latitude) plot locations plotAGB_X: Plot AGB values X threshold (e.g., plotAGB_10) mapAGB: Map AGB values extracted plot locations map_agb SpatRaster object containing AGB map layer. typically map used invDasymetry comparison. Values Mg/ha. map_sd SpatRaster object containing standard deviation (uncertainty) layer associated AGB map. Values Mg/ha. covariates Named list SpatRaster objects containing predictor variables. Common covariates include: height: Canopy height (e.g., Potapov et al. 2020) biome: Biome classification (e.g., Dinerstein et al. 2017) treecover: Tree cover percentage (e.g., Sexton et al. 2015) slope: Terrain slope DEM (e.g., SRTM) aspect: Terrain aspect DEM ifl: Intact Forest Landscape indicator (binary) List names used column names output. Set NULL skip covariate extraction. plot_agb_col Character string specifying column name plot AGB plot_data. Default "plotAGB_10" (10% threshold). map_agb_col Character string specifying column name map AGB plot_data. Default "mapAGB".

title: Extract bias and covariate values at plot locations — extractBiasCovariates
text: data.frame containing original columns plot_data plus: bias Calculated bias (mapAGB - plotAGB), Mg/ha. Positive values indicate map overestimation, negative values indicate map underestimation. map Map AGB value extracted plot location, Mg/ha sd Map SD value extracted plot location, Mg/ha <covariate_names> One column covariate covariates list. Column names match list names. IFL covariate, NA values automatically converted 0.

title: Extract bias and covariate values at plot locations — extractBiasCovariates
text: function implements first step bias modeling workflow. bias calculated : $$bias = AGB_{map} - AGB_{plot}$$ Positive bias values indicate map overestimates AGB compared plot measurements, negative values indicate underestimation. extracted covariates used predictors Random Forest model spatially model bias patterns. raster extractions use bilinear interpolation default. function ensures input rasters matching coordinate reference systems (CRS). Plots NA values covariate retain NA, handled model training.

title: Extract bias and covariate values at plot locations — extractBiasCovariates
text: Araza, ., de Bruin, S., Herold, M., Quegan, S., Labriere, N., Rodriguez-Veiga, P., Avitabile, V., Santoro, M., Mitchard, E.T.., Ryan, C.M., Phillips, O.L., Willcock, S., Verbeeck, H., Carreiras, J., Hein, L., Schelhaas, M.J., & Pacheco-Pascagaza, .M. (2022). comprehensive framework assessing accuracy uncertainty global -ground biomass maps. Remote Sensing Environment, 272, 112917. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rse.2022.112917

title: Extract bias and covariate values at plot locations — extractBiasCovariates
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create synthetic rasters for demonstration library(terra) r <- rast(ncol = 100, nrow = 100, xmin = -10, xmax = 10, ymin = 35, ymax = 45,           crs = "EPSG:4326") map_agb <- setValues(r, runif(ncell(r), 50, 300)) map_sd <- setValues(r, runif(ncell(r), 10, 50)) height <- setValues(r, runif(ncell(r), 5, 30)) treecover <- setValues(r, runif(ncell(r), 20, 100))  # Create sample plot data (e.g., from invDasymetry output) plot_data <- data.frame(   x = runif(50, -5, 5),   y = runif(50, 40, 45),   plotAGB_10 = runif(50, 40, 250),   mapAGB = runif(50, 60, 280) )  # Create named list of covariates covariates <- list(height = height, treecover = treecover)  # Extract bias and covariates at plot locations bias_data <- extractBiasCovariates(   plot_data = plot_data,   map_agb = map_agb,   map_sd = map_sd,   covariates = covariates,   plot_agb_col = "plotAGB_10",   map_agb_col = "mapAGB" )  # View results head(bias_data) cat("Mean bias:", mean(bias_data$bias, na.rm = TRUE), "Mg/ha\n") cat("Bias range:", range(bias_data$bias, na.rm = TRUE), "Mg/ha\n") } # }

what: Fit Variogram to Residuals After Bias Modeling — fitResidualVariogram
title: Fit Variogram to Residuals After Bias Modeling — fitResidualVariogram
text: Fits variogram model scaled residuals bias modeling characterize spatial autocorrelation remaining prediction errors. critical step uncertainty quantification allows proper aggregation standard errors accounting spatial correlation.

title: Fit Variogram to Residuals After Bias Modeling — fitResidualVariogram
code: fitResidualVariogram(   bias_data,   map_sd_raster,   model = "Sph",   cutoff = 50,   width = cutoff/15,   psill = 3,   range = 10,   nugget = 4,   coord_cols = c("lon", "lat"),   crs = "EPSG:4326",   remove_outliers = TRUE,   plot = TRUE )

title: Fit Variogram to Residuals After Bias Modeling — fitResidualVariogram
text: bias_data data.frame plot locations bias modeling results. Must contain columns: bias (observed bias), biasPred (predicted bias trainBiasModel()), coordinates (lon/lat x/y), joined SD values map_sd_raster. map_sd_raster SpatRaster containing pixel-level standard deviation AGB (Mg/ha). Used scale residuals: resid = (bias - biasPred) / sd. model Character. Variogram model type fit. Options: "Sph" (Spherical, default), "Exp" (Exponential), "Gau" (Gaussian), "Mat" (Matern). See gstat::vgm() details. cutoff Numeric. Maximum distance kilometers variogram calculation. Default: 50. roughly half maximum distance plots. function automatically converts meters UTM transformation. width Numeric. Width distance bins kilometers empirical variogram. Default: cutoff/15. Smaller values give detail noise. psill Numeric. Initial partial sill variogram fitting. Default: 3. Adjust based variance scaled residuals. range Numeric. Initial range parameter kilometers. Default: 10. Represents distance correlation becomes negligible. nugget Numeric. Initial nugget (y-intercept) variogram. Default: 4. Represents measurement error micro-scale variation. coord_cols Character vector length 2. Column names coordinates bias_data. Default: c("lon", "lat"). Use c("x", "y") data already projected. crs Character numeric. Coordinate reference system bias_data. Default: "EPSG:4326" (WGS84). Must match map_sd_raster CRS transformable . remove_outliers Logical. extreme residuals (|resid| > 3) removed variogram fitting? Default: TRUE. Helps prevent fitting issues. plot Logical. diagnostic plot generated? Default: TRUE. Shows empirical variogram points fitted model curve.

title: Fit Variogram to Residuals After Bias Modeling — fitResidualVariogram
text: list class "residualVariogram" containing: variogram_model gstat vgm object fitted variogram parameters empirical_variogram gstat variogram object empirical semivariances residuals data.frame columns: coordinates, bias, biasPred, sd, resid0 (raw residuals), resid (scaled residuals) resid_sf sf object residuals (used variogram fitting) fit_quality data.frame fitting diagnostics: SSErr (sum squared errors), RMSE, R2 (pseudo-R²) n_obs Integer. Number observations used fitting n_removed Integer. Number outliers removed (remove_outliers=TRUE) plot ggplot object plot=TRUE, NULL otherwise

title: Fit Variogram to Residuals After Bias Modeling — fitResidualVariogram
text: function implements residual variogram fitting approach following workflow: Extract SD values plot locations map_sd_raster Calculate raw residuals: resid0 = bias - biasPred Scale residuals map SD: resid = resid0 / sd Optionally remove outliers (|resid| > 3) Convert sf object gstat Fit empirical variogram gstat::variogram() Fit theoretical variogram model gstat::fit.variogram() Scaled residuals: Scaling SD critical standardizes residuals unitless values, allowing variogram fitting across regions different absolute error magnitudes. fitted variogram used create correlation matrices uncertainty aggregation. Model selection: default "Sph" (Spherical) model appropriate ecological data reaches finite sill defined range. Use "Exp" (Exponential) correlation decays gradually, "Gau" (Gaussian) smooth spatial processes. Initial parameters: psill, range, nugget parameters starting values nonlinear optimization. Poor initial values can lead convergence issues. Inspect empirical variogram first choose reasonable starting values.

title: Fit Variogram to Residuals After Bias Modeling — fitResidualVariogram
text: Araza, ., de Bruin, S., Herold, M., Quegan, S., Labrière, N., Rodriguez-Veiga, P., ... & Burt, . (2022). comprehensive framework assessing accuracy uncertainty global -ground biomass maps. Remote Sensing Environment, 272, 112917. Christensen, W. F. (2011). Filtered kriging spatial data heterogeneous measurement error variances. Biometrics, 67(3), 947-957.

title: Fit Variogram to Residuals After Bias Modeling — fitResidualVariogram
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Assuming you've run bias modeling workflow: # 1. Extract covariates and calculate bias bias_data <- extractBiasCovariates(   plot_data = plots,   map_agb = agb_map,   map_sd = sd_map,   covariates = list(height = height_raster, treecover = tc_raster) )  # 2. Train bias model bias_model <- trainBiasModel(   bias_data = bias_data,   predictors = c("map", "sd", "height", "treecover"),   cv_folds = 10 )  # 3. Add predictions to bias_data bias_data$biasPred <- predict(bias_model$model, data = bias_data)  # 4. Fit residual variogram vgm_fit <- fitResidualVariogram(   bias_data = bias_data,   map_sd_raster = sd_map,   model = "Sph",   cutoff = 50,   psill = 3,   range = 10,   nugget = 4,   coord_cols = c("x", "y"),   crs = "EPSG:4326" )  # Inspect results print(vgm_fit$variogram_model) print(vgm_fit$fit_quality) print(vgm_fit$plot)  # Check residual distribution hist(vgm_fit$residuals$resid, main = "Scaled Residuals") summary(vgm_fit$residuals$resid) } # }

title: Inverse dasymetric mapping — invDasymetry
text: plot_data data.frame, Plot dataset containing required columns: "POINT_X", "POINT_Y", "AGB_T_HA_ORIG", "AGB_T_HA", "SIZE_HA", "varPlot". "varPlot" column (plot measurement variance) automatically calculated using calculateTotalUncertainty() missing. applies aggregated non-aggregated modes. clmn character, Column name plot selection (e.g., "ZONE", "CONTINENT"). Set NULL process plots without filtering (default: "ZONE"). value character, Value select specified column (e.g., "Europe", "Africa"). Ignored clmn NULL (default: "Europe"). aggr numeric, Aggregation factor degrees (e.g., 0.1 0.1-degree cells). Set NULL aggregation. aggregated, plots falling within grid cell combined using inverse variance weighting. minPlots integer, Minimum number plots per aggregated cell. Cells fewer plots excluded. weighted_mean Logical, TRUE weighted mean calculated considering approximate fraction cell covered roi (default FALSE). is_poly logical, Whether input plots polygons (TRUE) converted polygons (FALSE). dataset Character, dataset use AGB estimation. Options "custom", "esacci", "gedi". Default "custom". agb_raster_path character, File path custom AGB raster. forest_mask_path character, File path forest mask raster. threshold numeric, Threshold (0-100) tree cover calculation forest masking (e.g. 0 10). pixels tree cover percentage threshold contribute biomass estimates. map_year numeric, year map data. provided, detected automatically available data sources. Used uncertainty calculation. map_resolution numeric, resolution map data degrees. provided, detected automatically available data sources. Used uncertainty calculation (sampling error component). esacci_biomass_year ESA CCI BIOMASS AGB tiles year use. Use either 2010, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022 "latest" (default). esacci_biomass_version ESA CCI BIOMASS AGB tiles version use. Use either "v2.0", "v3.0", "v4.0", "v5.0", "v5.01", "v6.0" "latest" (default). esacci_folder Directory save downloaded ESA CCI BIOMASS AGB files. Default relative path "data/ESACCI-BIOMASS". gedi_l4b_folder Character, folder save downloaded GeoTIFF file. Default "data/GEDI_L4B/". gedi_l4b_band Character, band filter . See options Details section . Default "MU". gedi_l4b_resolution Numeric, spatial resolution processed output GeoTIFF degrees. native resolution GEDI L4B gridded dataset 1 km, approximately 0.001 degrees equator. Default 0.001. gfc_folder Character string specifying directory download GFC data. gfc_dataset_year Numeric value describing version Hansen data use: year 2018-2023 range "latest" (default). timeout Number seconds reaching file download timeout. parallel logical, Enable parallel processing faster computation multi-core systems. Default FALSE. n_cores numeric, Number cores use parallel processing. memfrac numeric, Memory fraction (0-1) Terra use main process. Default 0.3. worker_memfrac numeric, Memory fraction (0-1) Terra use worker process parallel execution (future use - currently fixed 0.2 internally). Default 0.2. batch_size integer, Number plots process batch better memory management. NULL (default), batch size auto-determined based dataset size. crop_rasters logical, Whether crop rasters region interest processing (TRUE default). Set FALSE encounter issues cropping plots widely dispersed.

title: Inverse dasymetric mapping — invDasymetry
text: data frame following columns: plotAGB_X AGB values given forest threshold, X threshold value (e.g., plotAGB_10 threshold=10). aggregated, values derived weighted means using inverse variance weighting. Units tonnes per hectare (t/ha). tfPlotAGB Tree-filtered plot AGB (aggregated). equivalent AGB_T_HA values input data. orgPlotAGB Original plot AGB, derived AGB_T_HA_ORIG input data. mapAGB AGB map sampling, representing biomass values extracted reference map plot cell location. SIZE_HA Plot size hectares. aggregated cells, mean plot size within cell. varPlot Plot measurement variance (t/ha)². Includes measurement error, sampling error, growth uncertainty components. non-aggregated mode, individual plot variance. aggregated mode, combined using inverse variance weighting: 1 / sum(1/varPlot). n Number plots aggregated per cell (aggr specified). x X-coordinate plot cell center (longitude). y Y-coordinate plot cell center (latitude).

title: Inverse dasymetric mapping — invDasymetry
text: function performs inverse dasymetric mapping key steps: Plot Selection: Selects plots based specified criteria (clmn value). Spatial Processing (two modes): Non-Aggregated Mode (aggr = NULL): plot processed individually. Tree cover percentage calculated plot Biomass values adjusted based tree cover percentage Aggregated Mode (e.g., aggr = 0.1): Plots grouped grid cells. New grid cell coordinates calculated using integer division Plot measurements aggregated using inverse variance weighting Cells insufficient plot counts (less minPlots) filtered Forest Cover Correction: Tree cover percentage calculated plot cell forest pixels (based threshold) contribute biomass estimates Map Comparison: AGB values sampled reference maps Enables direct comparison field-measured map-estimated biomass

title: Inverse dasymetric mapping — invDasymetry
text: Ensure required columns present input plot data. parallel processing, adjust n_cores based system's capabilities. Large datasets may require significant processing time memory. function automatically calculates varPlot using calculateTotalUncertainty() missing.

title: Inverse dasymetric mapping — invDasymetry
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic usage with sample data library(Plot2Map) data(plots)  # Create a sample dataset and process it set.seed(42) sampled_plots <- plots[sample(nrow(plots), 100), ] plot_data <- Deforested(sampled_plots, gfc_folder = "data/GFC", map_year = 2020) plot_data <- BiomePair(plot_data$non_deforested_plots) plot_data <- TempApplyVar(plot_data, 2020)  # Example 1: Non-aggregated mode with custom AGB raster result_individual <- invDasymetry(   plot_data = plot_data,   clmn = "ZONE",   value = "Europe",   aggr = NULL,  # No aggregation   threshold = 10,  # 10% tree cover threshold   dataset = "custom",   agb_raster_path = "path/to/agb_raster.tif" )  # Example 2: Aggregated mode with ESA CCI data result_aggregated <- invDasymetry(   plot_data = plot_data,   clmn = "ZONE",   value = "Europe",   aggr = 0.25,  # 0.25° aggregation   minPlots = 2,  # Minimum 2 plots per cell   threshold = 10,   dataset = "esacci",   esacci_biomass_year = "latest" )  # Example 3: Process all plots without filtering (no zone selection) result_all_plots <- invDasymetry(   plot_data = plot_data,   clmn = NULL,  # No filtering - process all plots   threshold = 10,   dataset = "esacci" )  # Compare plot AGB with map AGB plot(   result_aggregated$plotAGB_10,   result_aggregated$mapAGB,   xlab = "Plot AGB (t/ha)",   ylab = "Map AGB (t/ha)",   main = "Plot vs Map Biomass Comparison" ) abline(0, 1, col = "red")  # 1:1 line } # }

title: Predict bias wall-to-wall across study region — predictBiasMap
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Following from trainBiasModel example # Assuming bias_model is already created  # Create covariate stack matching model predictors library(terra) r <- rast(ncol = 100, nrow = 100, xmin = -10, xmax = 10, ymin = 35, ymax = 45) map_layer <- setValues(r, runif(ncell(r), 0, 300)) sd_layer <- setValues(r, runif(ncell(r), 10, 50)) height_layer <- setValues(r, runif(ncell(r), 5, 30)) treecover_layer <- setValues(r, runif(ncell(r), 0, 100))  # Stack covariates with correct names covs <- c(map_layer, sd_layer, height_layer, treecover_layer) names(covs) <- c("map", "sd", "height", "treecover")  # Predict bias across region bias_map <- predictBiasMap(   bias_model = bias_model,   covariate_stack = covs )  # Plot results plot(bias_map, main = "Predicted Bias (Mg/ha)")  # Save to file bias_map <- predictBiasMap(   bias_model = bias_model,   covariate_stack = covs,   filename = "predicted_bias.tif",   overwrite = TRUE ) } # }

title: Calculate AGB and standard deviations from tree-level data — sd_tree
text: data frame plot-level AGB estimates standard deviations, including columns: PLOT_ID Unique identifier plot. POINT_X X-coordinate plot location. POINT_Y Y-coordinate plot location. SIZE_HA Plot size hectares. AVG_YEAR Average year measurement across trees plot. AGB_T_HA Ground Biomass scaled tons per hectare. sdTree Standard deviation AGB within plot.

title: Calculate AGB and standard deviations from tree-level data — sd_tree
text: function performs following steps: Flexible column dDetection: automatically detects maps column name variations standard names. function provides information columns used. Taxonomic correction: applies BIOMASS::correctTaxo() standardize genus species names, preference accepted taxonomic names (e.g., Genus_accepted genus). Uses retry mechanism handle temporary API failures/delays. Filters trees diameter >= 10cm. Retrieves wood density data using corrected taxonomy. Computes uses provided tree height data. height data missing brms package unavailable, automatically detects Feldpausch regions using coordinates BIOMASS::computeFeldRegion() height-diameter relationships. Runs Monte Carlo simulation AGB estimation. Calculates plot-level AGB standard deviation. Scales values per hectare.

title: Calculate AGB and standard deviations from tree-level data — sd_tree
text: function resolves GitHub issue #6 providing robust column name detection. handles common variations found real-world datasets, including: Research databases standardized column names (e.g., D_idtree, xutmr/yutmr) Field data simple column names (e.g., dbh, x/y) Taxonomically corrected data accepted names (e.g., Genus_accepted/Species_accepted) Various coordinate systems (UTM, lat/lon, etc.)

title: Calculate AGB and standard deviations from tree-level data — sd_tree
text: Feldpausch, T.R., et al. (2012). Tree height integrated pantropical forest biomass estimates. Biogeosciences, 9, 3381–3403.

title: Train Random Forest model to predict AGB map bias — trainBiasModel
code: trainBiasModel(   bias_data,   predictors = c("map", "sd", "height", "biome", "treecover", "slope", "aspect", "ifl"),   response = "bias",   method = "ranger",   seed = 1234,   cv_folds = NULL,   importance = TRUE,   ... )

title: Train Random Forest model to predict AGB map bias — trainBiasModel
text: bias_data data.frame output extractBiasCovariates, containing bias values covariate columns. Must include columns specified predictors column specified response. predictors Character vector predictor variable names use model. column names bias_data. Common predictors include: "map", "sd", "height", "biome", "treecover", "slope", "aspect", "ifl". Default uses standard covariates. response Character string specifying response variable column name. Default "bias". method Character string specifying Random Forest implementation use. Options : "ranger" (default): Uses ranger package fast training "randomForest": Uses randomForest package seed Integer random seed ensure reproducibility. Default 1234. cv_folds Integer specifying number folds k-fold cross-validation. NULL (default), cross-validation performed. specified (e.g., 10), performs k-fold CV returns performance metrics. importance Logical indicating whether calculate variable importance. Default TRUE. ... Additional arguments passed ranger::ranger randomForest::randomForest.

title: Train Random Forest model to predict AGB map bias — trainBiasModel
text: list following components: model trained Random Forest model object (class "ranger" "randomForest" depending method) importance data.frame variable importance scores. ranger, uses impurity-based importance. randomForest, uses IncNodePurity. Sorted importance descending order. cv_results cv_folds specified, data.frame cross-validation metrics including RMSE, MAE, R-squared fold overall. NULL cv_folds NULL. formula model formula used predictors Character vector predictor names used method Character string indicating method used n_obs Number observations used training (removing NAs)

title: Train Random Forest model to predict AGB map bias — trainBiasModel
text: Random Forest model learns relationship environmental map covariates systematic bias AGB map. model trains relationship: $$bias = f(covariates) + \epsilon$$ bias = mapAGB - plotAGB, f() learned Random Forest. ranger package recommended faster training, especially large datasets performing cross-validation. function automatically removes rows NA values predictor response variable training. cv_folds specified, function performs k-fold cross-validation assess model performance. useful model evaluation comparison.

title: Train Random Forest model to predict AGB map bias — trainBiasModel
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Following from extractBiasCovariates example # Assuming bias_data is already created  # Train model with default settings bias_model <- trainBiasModel(   bias_data = bias_data,   predictors = c("map", "sd", "height", "treecover") )  # View variable importance print(bias_model$importance)  # Train with cross-validation bias_model_cv <- trainBiasModel(   bias_data = bias_data,   predictors = c("map", "sd", "height", "treecover"),   cv_folds = 10 )  # View CV performance print(bias_model_cv$cv_results) } # }
